abstract.para: &suse; offers now new tools with some interesting features to system administrators for online service pack migration. These are simple command line tools, an intuitive graphical user interface, support for rollback of service packs, and some more. This chapter explains how to do a service pack migration step by step with the new tools.

sect1.title: Supported Scenarios and Versions
sect1.para: &suse; supports the following scenarios, be it offline or online:

listitem.para: Boot DVD, flash disk, ISO image, &ay;, plain RPM and third-party tools

sect1.title: Service Pack Migration Workflow
sect1.para: A service pack migration can be executed by either &yast;, zypper, &ay;, RPM, or third-party tools. Only the first two are described in this chapter. Regardless of the method, a service pack migration consists of the following steps:

The list of migration targets depends on the products you have installed. If you have an extension installed for which the new SP is not yet available, it could be that no migration target is offered to you.

The list of migration targets available for your host will always be retrieved from the &scc; and depend on installed products or extensions and may change over time—which means that, for example, migration from &slea;12 GA to SP2 may be possible for one host, but not possible for another.

sect1.title: Canceling Service Pack Migration
sect1.para: You can cancel the service pack migration at some specific points:

listitem.para: Until the package upgrade starts, there are only minimal changes on the system, like for services and repositories. Restore /etc/zypp/repos.d/* to revert to the former state.
After the package upgrade starts, you can revert to the former state by using a Snapper snapshot and restore from backup.
After the migration target was selected, &scc; changes the repository data. To revert this state manually, use SUSEConnect --rollback.

sect1.title: Migrating with &yast; (Online Migration Tool)
sect1.para: To perform a service pack migration with &yast;, use the Online Migration tool. By default, &yast; does not install any packages from a third-party repository. If a package was installed from a third-party repository, &yast; prevents packages from being replaced with the same package coming from &suse;.

note.title: Increase of Installation Size
note.para: When performing the SP migration, &yast; will install all recommended packages. Especially in the case of custom minimal installations, this may increase the installation size of the system significantly. To change this default behaviour, adjust /etc/zypp/zypp.conf and set the following variable:

sect1.para: This changes the behavior of all package operations, such as the installation of patches or new packages.
To start the service pack migration, do the following:

step.para: Install the latest updates to get the Online Migration module.
Install the package yast2-migration and its dependencies.
Restart &yast;, otherwise the newly installed module will not be shown in the control center.
Start the Online Migration module from the Software section in &yast;. &yast; will show possible migration targets and a summary.

&yast; allows you to skip a SP. If more than one migration targets are available for your system, you can select one SP from the list. This is useful, for example, if you want to reduce maintenance cost and downtime. Keep in mind, online migration for base products (&slsa;, &sleda;) remains available only between the SPs of a major version.
Select a migration target and proceed with Next.
In case the Online Migration tool offers update repositories, decide if you want them. It is recommended to proceed with Yes.

toms 2015-09-09: FATE#319140If the Online Migration tool finds obsolete repositories coming from DVD or a local server, it is highly recommended to disable them. Old repositories from SCC or SMT are removed automatically.
Check the summary and proceed with the migration by clicking Next. Confirm with Start Update.
After the successful migration restart your system.

sect1.title: Migrating with Zypper
sect1.para: To perform a service pack migration with Zypper, use the command line tool zypper migration.

note.title: Increase of Installation Size
note.para: When performing the SP migration, &yast; will install all recommended packages. Especially in the case of custom minimal installations, this may increase the installation size of the system significantly. To change this default behaviour, adjust /etc/zypp/zypp.conf and set the following variables:

sect1.para: This changes the behavior of all package operations, such as the installation of patches or new packages. To change the behavior of Zypper for a single invocation, add the parameter --no-recommends to your command line.
To start the service pack migration, do the following:

Install the latest updates.
Install the packages zypper-migration-plugin and their dependencies.
Run zypper migration:
